Notes on Mathematical Methods for Physicists Chapter3

本文最后更新于 2024年8月5日 晚上

Notes on Mathematical Methods for Physicists \S3

Chapter3 Vector Analysis

\S3.1 Review of Basic Properties

​ (1)

A+B=B+A(A+B)+C=A+(B+C)\begin{aligned} \bold{A}+\bold{B}&=\bold{B}+\bold{A}\\\\ (\bold{A}+\bold{B})+\bold{C}&=\bold{A}+(\bold{B}+\bold{C})\\\\ \end{aligned}A+B(A+B)+C​=B+A=A+(B+C)​

​ (2)

\begin{aligned} \abs{k\bold{A}}=\abs{k}\abs{\bold{A}}\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ (3) Vector polynomials (e.g. A−2B+3C\bold{A}-\bold{2B}+\bold{3C}A−2B+3C) are well-defined.

​ (4) Unit vectors e^i\hat{\bold{e}}_ie^i​.

A=A1e^1+A2e^2+⋯\begin{aligned} \bold{A}=A_1\hat{\bold{e}}_1+A_2\hat{\bold{e}}_2+\cdots\\\\ \end{aligned}A=A1​e^1​+A2​e^2​+⋯​

​ (5) Magnitude

\begin{aligned} \abs{\bold{A}}=(A_1^2+A_2^2+\cdots)^{1/2}\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ (6) Dot product

\begin{aligned} \bold{A}\cdot\bold{B}&=A_1B_1+A_2B_2+\cdots\\\\ \abs{\bold{A}}^2=\bold{A}\cdot\bold{A}\,&,\quad\bold{A}\cdot\bold{B}=\abs{\bold{A}}\abs{\bold{B}}\cos\theta\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ (7) Orthogonal

A⋅B=0 ,A ,B≠0e^i⋅e^j=δij\begin{aligned} \bold{A}\cdot\bold{B}=0\,&,\quad\bold{A}\,,\bold{B}\neq\bold{0}\\\\ \hat{\bold{e}}_i\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_j&=\delta_{ij}\\\\ \end{aligned}A⋅B=0e^i​⋅e^j​​,A,B=0=δij​​

​ (8) Projection

Ai=e^i⋅A\begin{aligned} A_i=\hat{\bold{e}}_i\cdot\bold{A}\\\\ \end{aligned}Ai​=e^i​⋅A​

​ (9) Direction cosines

Ax=Acos⁡α ,Ay=Acos⁡β ,Az=Acos⁡γcos⁡2α+cos⁡2β+cos⁡2γ=1A   is   in   R3\begin{aligned} A_x=A\cos\alpha\,,\quad A_y&=A\cos\beta\,,\quad A_z=A\cos\gamma\\\\ \cos^2\alpha+\cos^2&\beta+\cos^2\gamma=1\\\\ \bold{A}\,\,\,is\,&\,\,in\,\,\,\R^3\\\\ \end{aligned}Ax​=Acosα,Ay​cos2α+cos2Ais​=Acosβ,Az​=Acosγβ+cos2γ=1inR3​

​ (10) Single-column matrix

A⟹a=⟮A1A2A3⟯\begin{aligned} \bold{A}\Longrightarrow\bold{a}=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}A_1\\A_2\\A_3\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\ \end{aligned}A⟹a=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​A1​A2​A3​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​​

​ (11) The addition and multiplication of vectors can also be replaced by single-column matrices.

​ (12) Transpose of a single-column matrix , called a row vector\textbf{row vector}row vector.

aT=⟮A1A2A3⟯\begin{aligned} \bold{a}^T=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}A_1&A_2&A_3\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\ \end{aligned}aT=⎩⎪⎧​A1​​A2​​A3​​⎭⎪⎫​​

​ (13) Dot product replaced by multiplication of matrices

A⋅B=aTb=⟮A1A2A3⟯⟮A1A2A3⟯=A1B1+A2B2+A3B3\begin{aligned} \bold{A}\cdot\bold{B}=\bold{a}^T\bold{b}=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}A_1&A_2&A_3\end{array}\right\rgroup\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}A_1\\A_2\\A_3\end{array}\right\rgroup=A_1B_1+A_2B_2+A_3B_3\\\\ \end{aligned}A⋅B=aTb=⎩⎪⎧​A1​​A2​​A3​​⎭⎪⎫​⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​A1​A2​A3​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​=A1​B1​+A2​B2​+A3​B3​​

\S3.2 Vectors in 3−D3-D3−D Space

□\square□ Vectors or Cross Product

​ Definition :

\begin{aligned} \bold{C}=\bold{A}\cross\bold{B}=(AB\sin\theta)\hat{\bold{e}}_C\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ The direction of C\bold{C}C , i.e., that of e^C\hat{\bold{e}}_Ce^C​ , is perpendicular to the plane of A\bold{A}A and B\bold{B}B , such that A\bold{A}A , B\bold{B}B , and C\bold{C}C form a right-handed system.

\begin{aligned} \bold{C}&=\bold{A}\cross\bold{B}\\&=(A_x\hat{\bold{e}}_x+A_y\hat{\bold{e}}_y+A_z\hat{\bold{e}}_z)\cross(B_x\hat{\bold{e}}_x+B_y\hat{\bold{e}}_y+B_z\hat{\bold{e}}_z)\\&=(A_xB_y-A_yB_x)(\hat{\bold{e}}_x\cross\hat{\bold{e}}_y)+(A_xB_z-A_zB_x)(\hat{\bold{e}}_x\cross\hat{\bold{e}}_z)+\\&\quad\,(A_yB_z-A_zB_y)(\hat{\bold{e}}_y\cross\hat{\bold{e}}_z)\\&=(A_xB_y-A_yB_x)\hat{\bold{e}}_z+(A_zB_x-A_xB_z)\hat{\bold{e}}_y+(A_zB_y-A_yB_z)\hat{\bold{e}}_x\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ This can be equivalently represented as

\begin{aligned} C_i&=\sum_{jk}\varepsilon_{ijk}A_jB_k=\varepsilon_{ijk}A_jB_k\\ (Einstein&\,\,\,summation\,\,\,convention)\\\\ or&\quad\bold{C}=\left\arrowvert\begin{array}{lr}\hat{\bold{e}}_x&\hat{\bold{e}}_y&\hat{\bold{e}}_z\\A_x&A_y&A_z\\B_x&B_y&B_z\end{array}\right\arrowvert\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ Note that the cross product is a quantity specifically defined for 3−D3-D3−D space.

□\square□ Scalar Triple Product

​ Definition :

\begin{aligned} \bold{A}\cdot(\bold{B}\cross\bold{C})=\left\arrowvert\begin{array}{lr}A_x&A_y&A_z\\B_x&B_y&B_z\\C_x&C_y&C_z\end{array}\right\arrowvert\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ This quantity is equivalent to the volume of the space in the picture above.

​ There is

\begin{aligned} \bold{A}\cdot(\bold{B}\cross\bold{C})=\bold{B}\cdot(\bold{C}\cross\bold{A})=\bold{C}\cdot(\bold{A}\cross\bold{B})=-\bold{A}\cdot(\bold{C}\cross\bold{B})\,,\quad etc.\\\\ \end{aligned}

Example Reciprocal Lattice

​ Let a\bold{a}a , b\bold{b}b , and c\bold{c}c (not necessarily mutually perpendicular) represent the vectors that define a crystal lattice. The displacements from one lattice point to another may then be written

R=naa+nbb+ncc\begin{aligned} \bold{R}=n_a\bold{a}+n_b\bold{b}+n_c\bold{c}\\\\ \end{aligned}R=na​a+nb​b+nc​c​

​ In the band theory of solids , it is useful to introduce what is called a reciprocal lattice\textbf{reciprocal lattice}reciprocal lattice a′\bold{a}'a′ , b′\bold{b}'b′ , c′\bold{c}'c′ such that

a⋅a′=b⋅b′=c⋅c′=1\begin{aligned} \bold{a}\cdot\bold{a}'=\bold{b}\cdot\bold{b}'=\bold{c}\cdot\bold{c}'=1\\\\ \end{aligned}a⋅a′=b⋅b′=c⋅c′=1​

​ and with

a⋅b′=b⋅c′=c⋅a′=⋯=0\begin{aligned} \bold{a}\cdot\bold{b}'=\bold{b}\cdot\bold{c}'=\bold{c}\cdot\bold{a}'=\cdots=0\\\\ \end{aligned}a⋅b′=b⋅c′=c⋅a′=⋯=0​

​ Then

\begin{aligned} \bold{a}'=\frac{\bold{b}\cross\bold{c}}{\bold{a}\cdot(\bold{b}\cross\bold{c})}\,,\quad \bold{b}'=\frac{\bold{c}\cross\bold{a}}{\bold{a}\cdot(\bold{b}\cross\bold{c})}\,,\quad \bold{c}'=\frac{\bold{a}\cross\bold{b}}{\bold{a}\cdot(\bold{b}\cross\bold{c})}.\\\\ \end{aligned}

□\square□ Vector Triple Product

\begin{aligned} \bold{A}\cross(\bold{B}\cross\bold{C})=\bold{B}(\bold{A}\cdot\bold{C})-\bold{C}(\bold{A}\cdot\bold{B})\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ The equation can be proved by Levi-Civita symbols and Kronecker delta. There is

εijkεklm=εkijεklm=δilδjm−δimδjl\begin{aligned} \varepsilon_{ijk}\varepsilon_{klm}=\varepsilon_{kij}\varepsilon_{klm}=\delta_{il}\delta_{jm}-\delta_{im}\delta_{jl}\\\\ \end{aligned}εijk​εklm​=εkij​εklm​=δil​δjm​−δim​δjl​​

\S3.3 Coordinate Transformations

□\square□ Rotations

​ Rotate the axis as the picture below

e^x=cos⁡φe^x′−sin⁡φe^y′ ,ande^y=sin⁡φe^x′+cos⁡φe^y′\begin{aligned} \hat{\bold{e}}_x=\cos\varphi\hat{\bold{e}}'_x-\sin\varphi\hat{\bold{e}}'_y\,,\quad and\quad\hat{\bold{e}}_y=\sin\varphi\hat{\bold{e}}'_x+\cos\varphi\hat{\bold{e}}'_y\\\\ \end{aligned}e^x​=cosφe^x′​−sinφe^y′​,ande^y​=sinφe^x′​+cosφe^y′​​

​ So the unchanged\textbf{unchanged}unchanged vector A\bold{A}A now takes the changed\textbf{changed}changed form

A=Axe^x+Aye^y=Ax(cos⁡φe^x′−sin⁡φe^y′)+Ay(sin⁡φe^x′+cos⁡φe^y′)=(Axcos⁡φ+Aysin⁡φ)e^x′+(−Axsin⁡φ+Aycos⁡φ)e^y′⟹Ax′=Axcos⁡φ+Aysin⁡φ ,Ay′=−Axsin⁡φ+Aycos⁡φ\begin{aligned}\bold{A}&=A_x\hat{\bold{e}}_x+A_y\hat{\bold{e}}_y\\&=A_x(\cos\varphi\hat{\bold{e}}'_x-\sin\varphi\hat{\bold{e}}'_y)+A_y(\sin\varphi\hat{\bold{e}}'_x+\cos\varphi\hat{\bold{e}}'_y)\\&=(A_x\cos\varphi+A_y\sin\varphi)\hat{\bold{e}}'_x+(-A_x\sin\varphi+A_y\cos\varphi)\hat{\bold{e}}_y'\\\Longrightarrow A_x'&=A_x\cos\varphi+A_y\sin\varphi\,,\quad A_y'=-A_x\sin\varphi+A_y\cos\varphi\\\\\end{aligned}A⟹Ax′​​=Ax​e^x​+Ay​e^y​=Ax​(cosφe^x′​−sinφe^y′​)+Ay​(sinφe^x′​+cosφe^y′​)=(Ax​cosφ+Ay​sinφ)e^x′​+(−Ax​sinφ+Ay​cosφ)e^y′​=Ax​cosφ+Ay​sinφ,Ay′​=−Ax​sinφ+Ay​cosφ​

​ which is equivalent to the matrix equation

A′=⟮Ax′Ay′⟯=⟮cos⁡φsin⁡φ−sin⁡φcos⁡φ⟯⟮AxAy⟯\begin{aligned} \bold{A}'=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}A_x'\\A_y'\end{array}\right\rgroup=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}\cos\varphi&\sin\varphi\\-\sin\varphi&\cos\varphi\end{array}\right\rgroup\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}A_x\\A_y\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\ \end{aligned}A′=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎧​Ax′​Ay′​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎫​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎧​cosφ−sinφ​sinφcosφ​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎫​⎩⎪⎪⎪⎧​Ax​Ay​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎫​​

​ It is easy to find that

S=⟮cos⁡φsin⁡φ−sin⁡φcos⁡φ⟯\begin{aligned} S=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}\cos\varphi&\sin\varphi\\-\sin\varphi&\cos\varphi\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\ \end{aligned}S=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎧​cosφ−sinφ​sinφcosφ​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎫​​

​ is orthogonal.

□\square□ Orthogonal Transformations

​ It is no accident that the transformation describing a rotation in R2\R^2R2 was orthogonal. We can rewrite S\bold{S}S as

S=⟮e^x′⋅e^xe^x′⋅e^ye^y′⋅e^xe^y′⋅e^y⟯\begin{aligned} S=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}\hat{\bold{e}}'_x\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_x&\hat{\bold{e}}'_x\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_y\\\hat{\bold{e}}'_y\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_x&\hat{\bold{e}}'_y\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_y\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\ \end{aligned}S=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎧​e^x′​⋅e^x​e^y′​⋅e^x​​e^x′​⋅e^y​e^y′​⋅e^y​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎫​​

​ Summary : The transformation from one orthogonal Cartesian coordinate system to another Cartesian system is described by an orthogonal\textbf{orthogonal}orthogonal matrix.

□\square□ Reflections

​ For simplicity , consider first the inversion\textbf{inversion}inversion operation , in which the sign of each coordinate is reversed. This will lead to

S=⟮−1000−1000−1⟯\begin{aligned} S=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{}-1&0&0\\0&-1&0\\0&0&-1\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\ \end{aligned}S=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​−100​0−10​00−1​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​​

​ which clearly results in det⁡S=−1\det S=-1detS=−1. The change in sign of the determinant corresponds to the change from a right-handed to a left-handed coordinate system (which cannot be accomplished by a rotation). Reflection about a plane also changes the sign of the determinant.

​ This formula for vector addition , multiplication by a scalar , and the dot product are unaffected by a reflection transformation of the coordinates , but this is not true of the cross product. To see this , look at one component :

Cx: AyBz−AzBy ⟶ (−Ay)(−Bz)−(−Az)(−By)=AyBz−AzBy.\begin{aligned} C_x:\,A_yB_z-A_zB_y\,\longrightarrow\,(-A_y)(-B_z)-(-A_z)(-B_y)=A_yB_z-A_zB_y.\\\\ \end{aligned}Cx​:Ay​Bz​−Az​By​⟶(−Ay​)(−Bz​)−(−Az​)(−By​)=Ay​Bz​−Az​By​.​

​ The unchanged vectors are called axial vectors\textbf{axial vectors}axial vectors , or pseudovectors\textbf{pseudovectors}pseudovectors , while the other are called polar vectors\textbf{polar vectors}polar vectors , or just vectors\textbf{vectors}vectors. There is

A′=SA(vectors) ,C′=det⁡(S)SC(pseudovectors).\begin{aligned} \bold{A}'=S\bold{A}&\quad(vectors)\,,\\\bold{C}'=\det(S)S\bold{C}&\quad(pseudovectors).\\\\ \end{aligned}A′=SAC′=det(S)SC​(vectors),(pseudovectors).​

​ It is easy to find that \bold{A}\cdot(\bold{B}\cross\bold{C}) changes sign in the transformation , so it is called a pseudoscalar\textbf{pseudoscalar}pseudoscalar. And the vector \bold{A}\cross(\bold{B}\cross\bold{C}) is a vector , so there is a general principle that a product with an odd number of pseudo quantities is “pseudo” , while those with even numbers of pseudo quantities are not.

□\square□ Successive Operations

​ Two transformations can be carried out successively. This rule is only true for rotations and/or reflections by applying their relevant orthogonal transformations.

A′=S(R′)S(R)A\bold{A}'=S(R')S(R)\bold{A}A′=S(R′)S(R)A

​ Notes :

​ 1.The operations take place in right-to-left order.

​ 2.The product of two orthogonal matrices is orthogonal , so the combined operation is an orthogonal transformation.

\S3.4 Rotations in R3\R^3R3

​ Rotations in R3\R^3R3 is important in practice , so we discuss now in some detail the treatment of rotations in R3\R^3R3. There is

S=⟮e^1′⋅e^1e^1′⋅e^2e^1′⋅e^3e^2′⋅e^1e^2′⋅e^2e^2′⋅e^3e^3′⋅e^1e^3′⋅e^2e^3′⋅e^3⟯⟹S=⟮∂x1/∂x1′∂x2/∂x1′∂x3/∂x1′∂x1/∂x2′∂x2/∂x2′∂x3/∂x2′∂x1/∂x3′∂x2/∂x3′∂x3/∂x3′⟯\begin{aligned} S&=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}\hat{\bold{e}}'_1\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_1&\hat{\bold{e}}'_1\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_2&\hat{\bold{e}}'_1\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_3\\\hat{\bold{e}}'_2\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_1&\hat{\bold{e}}'_2\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_2&\hat{\bold{e}}'_2\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_3\\\hat{\bold{e}}'_3\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_1&\hat{\bold{e}}'_3\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_2&\hat{\bold{e}}'_3\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_3\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\\Longrightarrow S=&\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}\partial x_1/\partial x'_1&\partial x_2/\partial x'_1&\partial x_3/\partial x'_1\\\partial x_1/\partial x'_2&\partial x_2/\partial x'_2&\partial x_3/\partial x'_2\\\partial x_1/\partial x'_3&\partial x_2/\partial x'_3&\partial x_3/\partial x'_3\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\ \end{aligned}S⟹S=​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​e^1′​⋅e^1​e^2′​⋅e^1​e^3′​⋅e^1​​e^1′​⋅e^2​e^2′​⋅e^2​e^3′​⋅e^2​​e^1′​⋅e^3​e^2′​⋅e^3​e^3′​⋅e^3​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​∂x1​/∂x1′​∂x1​/∂x2′​∂x1​/∂x3′​​∂x2​/∂x1′​∂x2​/∂x2′​∂x2​/∂x3′​​∂x3​/∂x1′​∂x3​/∂x2′​∂x3​/∂x3′​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​​

​ The argument we made to evaluate e^μ′⋅e^ν\hat{\bold{e}}'_\mu\cdot\hat{\bold{e}}_\nue^μ′​⋅e^ν​ could as easily have been made with the roles of the two unit vectors reversed

∂xν∂xμ′=∂xμ′∂xν\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial x_\nu}{\partial x'_\mu}=\frac{\partial x'_\mu}{\partial x_\nu}\\\\ \end{aligned}∂xμ′​∂xν​​=∂xν​∂xμ′​​​

​ In R2\R^2R2 , we find that all the elements of SSS depended on a single variable , the rotation angle. In R3\R^3R3 , the number of independent variables needed to specify a general rotation is three. The usual parameters used to specify R3\R^3R3 rotations are the Euler angles\textbf{Euler angles}Euler angles. The three steps describing rotation of the coordinate axes are the following :

​ (1) The coordinates are rotated about the e^3\hat{\bold{e}}_3e^3​ axis counterclockwise (as viewed from positive e^3\hat{\bold{e}}_3e^3​) through an angle α\alphaα in the range 0≤α<2π0\leq\alpha<2\pi0≤α<2π , into new axes denoted e^1′\hat{\bold{e}}'_1e^1′​ , e^2′\hat{\bold{e}}'_2e^2′​ , e^3′\hat{\bold{e}}'_3e^3′​. (The polar direction is not changed ; the e^3\hat{\bold{e}}_3e^3​ and e^3′\hat{\bold{e}}'_3e^3′​ axes coincide.)

​ (2) The coordinates are rotated about the e^2′\hat{\bold{e}}'_2e^2′​ axis counterclockwise (as viewed from positive e^2′\hat{\bold{e}}'_2e^2′​) through an angle β\betaβ in the range 0≤β≤π0\leq\beta\leq\pi0≤β≤π , into new axes denoted e^1′′\hat{\bold{e}}''_1e^1′′​ , e^2′′\hat{\bold{e}}''_2e^2′′​ , e^3′′\hat{\bold{e}}''_3e^3′′​. (This tilts the polar direction toward the e^1′\hat{\bold{e}}'_1e^1′​ direction , but leaves e^2′\hat{\bold{e}}'_2e^2′​ unchanged.)

​ (3) The coordinates are now rotated about the e^3′′\hat{\bold{e}}''_3e^3′′​ axis counterclockwise (as viewed from positive e^3′′\hat{\bold{e}}''_3e^3′′​) through an angle γ\gammaγ in the range 0≤γ<2π0\leq\gamma<2\pi0≤γ<2π , into the final axes , denoted e^1′′′\hat{\bold{e}}'''_1e^1′′′​ , e^2′′′\hat{\bold{e}}'''_2e^2′′′​ , e^3′′′\hat{\bold{e}}'''_3e^3′′′​. (This rotation leaves the polar direction , e^3′′\hat{\bold{e}}''_3e^3′′​ , unchanged.)

​ The matrices that represent those rotations are

S1(α)=⟮cos⁡αsin⁡α0−sin⁡αcos⁡α0001⟯S2(β)=⟮cos⁡β0−sin⁡β010sin⁡β0cos⁡β⟯S3(γ)=⟮cos⁡γsin⁡γ0−sin⁡γcos⁡γ0001⟯S(α,β,γ)=S3(γ)S2(β)S1(α)⇒S(α,β,γ)=\begin{aligned} S_1(\alpha)&=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{}\cos\alpha&\sin\alpha&0\\-\sin\alpha&\cos\alpha&0\\0&0&1\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\S_2(\beta)&=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{}\cos\beta&0&-\sin\beta\\0&1&0\\\sin\beta&0&\cos\beta\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\S_3(\gamma)&=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{}\cos\gamma&\sin\gamma&0\\-\sin\gamma&\cos\gamma&0\\0&0&1\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\S(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)&=S_3(\gamma)S_2(\beta)S_1(\alpha)\\\\\Rightarrow S(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)&=\\\\ \end{aligned}S1​(α)S2​(β)S3​(γ)S(α,β,γ)⇒S(α,β,γ)​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​cosα−sinα0​sinαcosα0​001​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​cosβ0sinβ​010​−sinβ0cosβ​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​cosγ−sinγ0​sinγcosγ0​001​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​=S3​(γ)S2​(β)S1​(α)=​

⟮cos⁡γcos⁡βcos⁡α−sin⁡γsin⁡αcos⁡γcos⁡βsin⁡α+sin⁡γcos⁡α−cos⁡γsin⁡β−sin⁡γcos⁡βcos⁡α−cos⁡γsin⁡α−sin⁡γcos⁡βsin⁡α+cos⁡γcos⁡αsin⁡γsin⁡βsin⁡βcos⁡αsin⁡βsin⁡αcos⁡β⟯\begin{aligned} \left\lgroup\begin{array}{}\cos\gamma\cos\beta\cos\alpha-\sin\gamma\sin\alpha&\cos\gamma\cos\beta\sin\alpha+\sin\gamma\cos\alpha&-\cos\gamma\sin\beta\\-\sin\gamma\cos\beta\cos\alpha-\cos\gamma\sin\alpha&-\sin\gamma\cos\beta\sin\alpha+\cos\gamma\cos\alpha&\sin\gamma\sin\beta\\\sin\beta\cos\alpha&\sin\beta\sin\alpha&\cos\beta\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\ \end{aligned}⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​cosγcosβcosα−sinγsinα−sinγcosβcosα−cosγsinαsinβcosα​cosγcosβsinα+sinγcosα−sinγcosβsinα+cosγcosαsinβsinα​−cosγsinβsinγsinβcosβ​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​​

​ Note the order of SSS.

​ Note that those matrices are orthogonal with determinant +1+1+1.

\S3.5 Differential Vector Operators

​ We are going to discuss vector field\textbf{vector field}vector field. Physicists need to be able to characterize the rate at which the values of vectors (and also scalars) change with position , and this is most effectively done by introducing differential vector operator concepts. It turns out that there are a large number of relations between these differential operators , and it is our current objective to identify such relations and learn how to use them.

□\square□ Gradient , ∇\nabla∇

​ The gradient\textbf{gradient}gradient characterizes the change of a scalar field , here φ\varphiφ , with position. There is

dφ=(∂φ∂x1)dx1+(∂φ∂x2)dx2+(∂φ∂x3)dx3\begin{aligned} d\varphi=(\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial x_1})dx_1+(\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial x_2})dx_2+(\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial x_3})dx_3\\\\ \end{aligned}dφ=(∂x1​∂φ​)dx1​+(∂x2​∂φ​)dx2​+(∂x3​∂φ​)dx3​​

​ which is of the form corresponding to the dot product of

∇φ=⟮∂φ/∂x1∂φ/∂x2∂φ/∂x3⟯anddr=⟮dx1dx2dx3⟯⟹dφ=(∇φ)⋅dr\begin{aligned} \nabla\varphi=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}\partial\varphi/\partial x_1\\\partial\varphi/\partial x_2\\\partial\varphi/\partial x_3\end{array}\right\rgroup\quad &and\quad d\bold{r}=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}dx_1\\dx_2\\dx_3\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\\Longrightarrow d\varphi&=(\nabla\varphi)\cdot d\bold{r}\\\\ \end{aligned}∇φ=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​∂φ/∂x1​∂φ/∂x2​∂φ/∂x3​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​⟹dφ​anddr=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​dx1​dx2​dx3​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​=(∇φ)⋅dr​

​ We have given the 3\cross1 matrix of derivatives the name ∇φ\nabla\varphi∇φ (often referred to in speech as “del phi” or “grad phi”) ; we give the differential of position its customary name drd\bold{r}dr.

​ The ∇φ\nabla\varphi∇φ is a vector. To prove this , we must show that it transforms under rotation of the coordinate system according to (∇φ)′=S(∇φ)(\nabla\varphi)'=S(\nabla\varphi)(∇φ)′=S(∇φ). We have

S(∇φ)=⟮∂x1/∂x1′∂x2/∂x1′∂x3/∂x1′∂x1/∂x2′∂x2/∂x2′∂x3/∂x2′∂x1/∂x3′∂x2/∂x3′∂x3/∂x3′⟯⟮∂φ/∂x1∂φ/∂x2∂φ/∂x3⟯=⟮∑ν=13∂xν∂x1′∂φ∂xν∑ν=13∂xν∂x2′∂φ∂xν∑ν=13∂xν∂x3′∂φ∂xν⟯.Q.E.D□\begin{aligned} S(\nabla\varphi)&=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}\partial x_1/\partial x'_1&\partial x_2/\partial x'_1&\partial x_3/\partial x'_1\\\partial x_1/\partial x'_2&\partial x_2/\partial x'_2&\partial x_3/\partial x'_2\\\partial x_1/\partial x'_3&\partial x_2/\partial x'_3&\partial x_3/\partial x'_3\end{array}\right\rgroup\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}\partial\varphi/\partial x_1\\\partial\varphi/\partial x_2\\\partial\varphi/\partial x_3\end{array}\right\rgroup\\\\&=\left\lgroup\begin{array}{lr}\overset{3}{\underset{\nu=1}{\sum}}\frac{\partial x_\nu}{\partial x'_1}\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial x_\nu}\\\overset{3}{\underset{\nu=1}{\sum}}\frac{\partial x_\nu}{\partial x'_2}\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial x_\nu}\\\overset{3}{\underset{\nu=1}{\sum}}\frac{\partial x_\nu}{\partial x'_3}\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial x_\nu}\end{array}\right\rgroup.\\\\&Q.E.D\quad\square\\\\ \end{aligned}S(∇φ)​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​∂x1​/∂x1′​∂x1​/∂x2′​∂x1​/∂x3′​​∂x2​/∂x1′​∂x2​/∂x2′​∂x2​/∂x3′​​∂x3​/∂x1′​∂x3​/∂x2′​∂x3​/∂x3′​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​∂φ/∂x1​∂φ/∂x2​∂φ/∂x3​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​ν=1∑​3​∂x1′​∂xν​​∂xν​∂φ​ν=1∑​3​∂x2′​∂xν​​∂xν​∂φ​ν=1∑​3​∂x3′​∂xν​​∂xν​∂φ​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎫​.Q.E.D□​

​ Having now established the legitimacy of the form ∇φ\nabla\varphi∇φ , we proceed to give ∇\nabla∇ a life of its own. We therefore define

∇=e^x∂∂x+e^y∂∂y+e^z∂∂z\begin{aligned} \nabla=\hat{\bold{e}}_x\frac{\partial}{\partial x}+\hat{\bold{e}}_y\frac{\partial}{\partial y}+\hat{\bold{e}}_z\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\\\\ \end{aligned}∇=e^x​∂x∂​+e^y​∂y∂​+e^z​∂z∂​​

​ Note that ∇\nabla∇ is a vector differential operator\textbf{vector differential operator}vector differential operator.

​ In physics , we have F(r)=−∇V(r)\bold{F}(\bold{r})=-\nabla V(\bold{r})F(r)=−∇V(r).

​ There is a simple geometric interpretation of the gradient : ∇V\nabla V∇V is the direction of most rapid increase in VVV , and its magnitude is associated with the speed of increasing.

Example Gradient of rnr^nrn

r=(x2+y2+z2)1/2∂r∂x=x(x2+y2+z2)1/2=xr ,∂r∂y=yr ,∂r∂z=zr⟹∇r=xre^x+yre^y+zre^z=rr∇r=r^⟹∇rn=nrn−1∇r=nrn−1r^r=(x^2+y^2+z^2)^{1/2}\\ \frac{\partial r}{\partial x}=\frac{x}{(x^2+y^2+z^2)^{1/2}}=\frac{x}{r}\,,\quad\frac{\partial r}{\partial y}=\frac{y}{r}\,,\quad\frac{\partial r}{\partial z}=\frac{z}{r}\\ \Longrightarrow\nabla r=\frac{x}{r}\hat{\bold{e}}_x+\frac{y}{r}\hat{\bold{e}}_y+\frac{z}{r}\hat{\bold{e}}_z=\frac{\bold{r}}{r}\\\nabla r=\hat{\bold{r}}\\ \Longrightarrow\nabla r^n=nr^{n-1}\nabla r=nr^{n-1}\hat{\bold{r}}\\\\r=(x2+y2+z2)1/2∂x∂r​=(x2+y2+z2)1/2x​=rx​,∂y∂r​=ry​,∂z∂r​=rz​⟹∇r=rx​e^x​+ry​e^y​+rz​e^z​=rr​∇r=r^⟹∇rn=nrn−1∇r=nrn−1r^

□\square□ Divergence , ∇⋅\nabla\cdot∇⋅

​ The divergence\textbf{divergence}divergence of a vector is defined as the operation

∇⋅A=∂Ax∂x+∂Ay∂y+∂Az∂z\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot\bold{A}=\frac{\partial A_x}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial A_y}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial A_z}{\partial z}\\\\ \end{aligned}∇⋅A=∂x∂Ax​​+∂y∂Ay​​+∂z∂Az​​​

Example Divergence of Central Force Field

​ Consider ∇⋅f(r)r^\nabla\cdot f(r)\hat{\bold{r}}∇⋅f(r)r^. We write

∇⋅f(r)r^=(e^x∂∂x+e^y∂∂y+e^z∂∂z)⋅(xf(r)re^x+yf(r)re^y+zf(r)re^z)=∂∂x(xf(r)r)+∂∂y(yf(r)r)+∂∂z(zf(r)r)\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot f(r)\hat{\bold{r}}&=(\hat{\bold{e}}_x\frac{\partial}{\partial x}+\hat{\bold{e}}_y\frac{\partial}{\partial y}+\hat{\bold{e}}_z\frac{\partial}{\partial z})\cdot(\frac{xf(r)}{r}\hat{\bold{e}}_x+\frac{yf(r)}{r}\hat{\bold{e}}_y+\frac{zf(r)}{r}\hat{\bold{e}}_z)\\&=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}(\frac{xf(r)}{r})+\frac{\partial}{\partial y}(\frac{yf(r)}{r})+\frac{\partial}{\partial z}(\frac{zf(r)}{r})\\\\ \end{aligned}∇⋅f(r)r^​=(e^x​∂x∂​+e^y​∂y∂​+e^z​∂z∂​)⋅(rxf(r)​e^x​+ryf(r)​e^y​+rzf(r)​e^z​)=∂x∂​(rxf(r)​)+∂y∂​(ryf(r)​)+∂z∂​(rzf(r)​)​

​ Using

∂∂x(xf(r)r)=f(r)r−xf(r)r2∂r∂x+xrdf(r)dr∂r∂x=f(r)[1r−x2r3]+x2r2df(r)dr\begin{aligned}\frac{\partial}{\partial x}(\frac{xf(r)}{r})&=\frac{f(r)}{r}-\frac{xf(r)}{r^2}\frac{\partial r}{\partial x}+\frac{x}{r}\frac{df(r)}{dr}\frac{\partial r}{\partial x}\\&=f(r)[\frac{1}{r}-\frac{x^2}{r^3}]+\frac{x^2}{r^2}\frac{df(r)}{dr}\\\\\end{aligned}∂x∂​(rxf(r)​)​=rf(r)​−r2xf(r)​∂x∂r​+rx​drdf(r)​∂x∂r​=f(r)[r1​−r3x2​]+r2x2​drdf(r)​​

​ We can simplify the equation :

∇⋅f(r)r^=2f(r)r+df(r)dr\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot f(r)\hat{\bold{r}}=2\frac{f(r)}{r}+\frac{df(r)}{dr}\\\\ \end{aligned}∇⋅f(r)r^=2rf(r)​+drdf(r)​​

​ Of course , I have already learnt about the origin of divergence ---- the representative of flux in a differential form. If the physical problem being described is one in which fluid (molecules) are neither created or destroyed , we will also have an equation of continuity\textbf{equation of continuity}equation of continuity , of the form

∂ρ∂t+∇⋅(ρv)=0\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial\rho}{\partial t}+\nabla\cdot(\rho\bold{v})=0\\\\ \end{aligned}∂t∂ρ​+∇⋅(ρv)=0​

​ If the divergence of a vector field is zero everywhere , its lines of force will entirely of closed loops ; such vector fields are termed solenoidal\textbf{solenoidal}solenoidal.

□\square□ Curl , \nabla\cross

\begin{aligned}\nabla\cross \bold{V}&=\hat{\bold{e}}_x(\frac{\partial}{\partial y}V_z-\frac{\partial}{\partial z}V_y)+\hat{\bold{e}}_y(\frac{\partial}{\partial z}V_x-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}V_z)+\hat{\bold{e}}_z(\frac{\partial}{\partial x}V_y-\frac{\partial}{\partial y}V_x)\\&=\left\lvert\begin{array}{}\hat{\bold{e}}_x&\hat{\bold{e}}_y&\hat{\bold{e}}_z\\\partial/\partial x&\partial/\partial y&\partial/\partial z\\V_x&V_y&V_z\end{array}\right\lvert\\\\\end{aligned}

​ This vector is called the curl\textbf{curl}curl of V\bold{V}V. Note that when the determinant is evaluated , it must be expanded in a way that causes the derivatives in the second row to be applied to the functions in the third row (and not to anything in the top row) ; we will encounter this situation repeatedly , and will identify the evaluation as being from the top down\textbf{from the top down}from the top down.

Example Curl of a Central Force Field

​ Consider \nabla\cross[f(r)\hat{\bold{r}}]. Writing

[\nabla\cross[f(r)\hat{\bold{r}}]]_x=0\\\\

​ so the result is 0.

​ Noting that a vector whose curl is zero everywhere is termed irrotational\textbf{irrotational}irrotational.

\S3.6 Differential Vector Operators : Further Properties

□\square□ Successive Applications of ∇\nabla∇

​ The possible results include the following :

\begin{aligned} &(a)\,\nabla\cdot\nabla\varphi\\ &(b)\,\nabla\cross\nabla\varphi\\ &(c)\,\nabla(\nabla\cdot\varphi)\\ &(d)\,\nabla\cdot(\nabla\cross\bold{V})\\ &(e)\,\nabla\cross(\nabla\cross\bold{V})\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ All five of these expressions involve second derivatives , and all five appear in the second-order differential equations of mathematical physics , particularly in electromagnetic theory.

□\square□ Laplacian

​ Laplacian is the divergence of the gradient. We have

∇⋅∇φ=(e^x∂∂x+e^y∂∂y+e^z∂∂z)⋅(e^x∂φ∂x+e^y∂φ∂y+e^z∂φ∂z)=∂2φ∂x2+∂2φ∂y2+∂2φ∂z2\begin{aligned}\nabla\cdot\nabla\varphi&=(\hat{\bold{e}}_x\frac{\partial}{\partial x}+\hat{\bold{e}}_y\frac{\partial}{\partial y}+\hat{\bold{e}}_z\frac{\partial}{\partial z})\cdot(\hat{\bold{e}}_x\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial x}+\hat{\bold{e}}_y\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial y}+\hat{\bold{e}}_z\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial z})\\&=\frac{\partial^2\varphi}{\partial x^2}+\frac{\partial^2\varphi}{\partial y^2}+\frac{\partial^2\varphi}{\partial z^2}\\\\\end{aligned}∇⋅∇φ​=(e^x​∂x∂​+e^y​∂y∂​+e^z​∂z∂​)⋅(e^x​∂x∂φ​+e^y​∂y∂φ​+e^z​∂z∂φ​)=∂x2∂2φ​+∂y2∂2φ​+∂z2∂2φ​​

​ When φ\varphiφ is the electrostatic potential , we have ∇⋅∇φ=0\nabla\cdot\nabla\varphi=0∇⋅∇φ=0 in vacuum. This is called the Laplacian equation\textbf{Laplacian equation}Laplacian equation.

​ Often the Laplacian is written as ∇2\nabla^2∇2 , or Δ\DeltaΔ in the older European literature.

Example Laplacian of a Central Field Potential

​ Calculate \laplacian\varphi(r).

\begin{aligned}\laplacian\varphi(r)&=\nabla\cdot\nabla\varphi\\&=\nabla\cdot\frac{d\varphi(r)}{dr}\hat{\bold{e}}_r\\&=\frac{2}{r}\frac{d\varphi(r)}{dr}+\frac{d^2\varphi(r)}{dr^2}\\\\\end{aligned}

□\square□ Irrotational and Solenoidal Vector Fields

​ The curl of the divergence :

\begin{aligned}\nabla\cross\nabla\varphi&=\left\lvert\begin{array}{}\hat{\bold{e}}_x&\hat{\bold{e}}_y&\hat{\bold{e}}_z\\\partial/\partial x&\partial/\partial y&\partial/\partial z\\\partial\varphi/\partial x&\partial\varphi/\partial y&\partial\varphi/\partial z\end{array}\right\lvert\\&=\left\lvert\begin{array}{}\hat{\bold{e}}_x&\hat{\bold{e}}_y&\hat{\bold{e}}_z\\\partial/\partial x&\partial/\partial y&\partial/\partial z\\\partial/\partial x&\partial/\partial y&\partial/\partial z\end{array}\right\lvert\,\varphi=0.\\\\\end{aligned}

​ The divergence of the curl :

\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot(\nabla\cross\bold{V})=\left\lvert\begin{array}{}\partial/\partial x&\partial/\partial y&\partial/\partial z\\\partial/\partial x&\partial/\partial y&\partial/\partial z\\V_x&V_y&V_z\end{array}\right\lvert=0.\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ We can thus see that the divergence is irrotational\textbf{irrotational}irrotational , and the curl is solenoidal\textbf{solenoidal}solenoidal. Therefore ,

\nabla\cross\nabla\varphi=0\,,\quad \forall\,\varphi\,;\\ \nabla\cdot(\nabla\cross\bold{V})=0\,,\quad\forall\,\bold{V}.\\\\

□\square□ Maxwell’s Equations

​ We who are learning physics all know this well.

\nabla\cdot\bold{B}=0\\ \nabla\cdot\bold{E}=\frac{\rho}{\varepsilon_0}\\ \nabla\cross\bold{B}=\varepsilon_0\mu_0\frac{\partial\bold{E}}{\partial t}+\mu_0\bold{J}\\ \nabla\cross\bold{E}=-\frac{\partial\bold{B}}{\partial t}\\\\

□\square□ Vector Laplacian

​ There is

\begin{aligned} \nabla\cross(\nabla\cross\bold{V})=\nabla(\nabla\cdot\bold{V})-\nabla\cdot\nabla\bold{V}\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ (This can be proved by Levi-Civita symbols.) The term ∇⋅∇V\nabla\cdot\nabla\bold{V}∇⋅∇V is called the vector Laplacian\textbf{vector Laplacian}vector Laplacian , written as \laplacian\bold{V}.

Example Electromagnetic Wave Equation

​ In vacuum , we can derive the Maxwell equation , and thus we have

\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\nabla\cross\bold{B}&=\varepsilon_0\mu_0\frac{\partial^2\bold{E}}{\partial t^2}\,,\\ \nabla\cross(\nabla\cross\bold{E})&=-\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\nabla\cross\bold{B}=-\varepsilon_0\mu_0\frac{\partial^2\bold{E}}{\partial t^2}.\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ Then the equation is decided only by E\bold{E}E. In vacuum , there is ∇⋅E=0\nabla\cdot\bold{E}=0∇⋅E=0. The result is the vector electromagnetic wave equation for E\bold{E}E ,

∇2E=ε0μ0∂2E∂t2=1c2∂2E∂t2\begin{aligned} \nabla^2\bold{E}=\varepsilon_0\mu_0\frac{\partial^2\bold{E}}{\partial t^2}=\frac{1}{c^2}\frac{\partial^2\bold{E}}{\partial t^2}\\\\ \end{aligned}∇2E=ε0​μ0​∂t2∂2E​=c21​∂t2∂2E​​

​ The components are three scalar wave equations.

□\square□ Miscellaneous Vector Identities

​ These are further examples of usages of ∇\nabla∇.

Example Divergence and Curl of a Product

​ First , simplify ∇⋅(f V)\nabla\cdot(f\,\bold{V})∇⋅(fV) ,

∇⋅(f V)=∂∂x(fVx)+∂∂y(fVy)+∂∂z(fVz)=∂f∂xVx+f∂Vx∂x+∂f∂yVy+f∂Vy∂y+∂f∂zVz+f∂Vz∂z=(∇f)⋅V+f∇⋅V\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot(f\,\bold{V})&=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}(fV_x)+\frac{\partial}{\partial y}(fV_y)+\frac{\partial}{\partial z}(fV_z)\\&=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}V_x+f\frac{\partial V_x}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}V_y+f\frac{\partial V_y}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial z}V_z+f\frac{\partial V_z}{\partial z}\\&=(\nabla f)\cdot\bold{V}+f\nabla\cdot\bold{V}\\\\ \end{aligned}∇⋅(fV)​=∂x∂​(fVx​)+∂y∂​(fVy​)+∂z∂​(fVz​)=∂x∂f​Vx​+f∂x∂Vx​​+∂y∂f​Vy​+f∂y∂Vy​​+∂z∂f​Vz​+f∂z∂Vz​​=(∇f)⋅V+f∇⋅V​

​ Now , simplify \nabla\cross(f\,\bold{V}). Consider the xxx-component :

∂∂y(fVz)−∂∂z(fVy)=f[∂Vz∂y−∂Vy∂z]+[∂f∂yVz−∂f∂zVy]\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial}{\partial y}(fV_z)-\frac{\partial}{\partial z}(fV_y)=f[\frac{\partial V_z}{\partial y}-\frac{\partial V_y}{\partial z}]+[\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}V_z-\frac{\partial f}{\partial z}V_y]\\\\ \end{aligned}∂y∂​(fVz​)−∂z∂​(fVy​)=f[∂y∂Vz​​−∂z∂Vy​​]+[∂y∂f​Vz​−∂z∂f​Vy​]​

​ This is the xxx-component of f(\nabla\cross\bold{V})+(\nabla f)\cross\bold{V} , so we have

\begin{aligned} \nabla\cross(f\,\bold{V})=f(\nabla\cross\bold{V})+(\nabla f)\cross\bold{V}\\\\ \end{aligned}

Example Gradient of a Dot Product

\begin{aligned} \nabla(\bold{A}\cdot\bold{B})=(\bold{B}\cdot\nabla)\bold{A}+(\bold{A}\cdot\nabla)\bold{B}+\bold{B}\cross(\nabla\cross\bold{A})+\bold{A}\cross(\nabla\cross\bold{B})\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ We can prove the equation by applying ∇A\nabla_A∇A​ and ∇B\nabla_B∇B​ , which operate only on A\bold{A}A or B\bold{B}B.

\S3.7 Vector Integration

□\square□ Line Integrals

​ Possible forms :

\begin{aligned} \int_C\varphi d\bold{r}\,,\quad\int_C\bold{F}\cdot d\bold{r}\,,\quad\int_C\bold{V}\cross d\bold{r}\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ These integrals are calculated over some path CCC.

□\square□ Surface Integrals

​ Possible forms :

\begin{aligned} \int_S\varphi d\bold{\sigma}\,\quad\int_S\bold{V}\cdot d\bold{\sigma}\,,\quad\int_S\bold{V}\cross d\bold{\sigma}\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ Here , dσd\bold{\sigma}dσ is n^dA\hat{\bold{n}}dAn^dA , where n^\hat{\bold{n}}n^ is a unit vector indicating the normal direction.

□\square□ Volume Integrals

∫Vdτ=e^x∫Vxdτ+e^y∫Vydτ+e^z∫Vzdτ\int\bold{V}d\tau=\hat{\bold{e}}_x\int V_xd\tau+\hat{\bold{e}}_y\int V_yd\tau+\hat{\bold{e}}_z\int V_zd\tau\\\\∫Vdτ=e^x​∫Vx​dτ+e^y​∫Vy​dτ+e^z​∫Vz​dτ

\S3.8 Integral Theorems

□\square□ Gauss’ Theorem

​ This theorem connects a surface integral of a vector to a volume integral of the of the divergence of the vector. Assume a vector A\bold{A}A and it is C1C^1C1 over a simply connected\textbf{simply connected}simply connected region of R3\R^3R3. Then Gauss’ theorem states that

∮∂VA⋅dσ=∫V∇⋅Adτ\begin{aligned} \oint_{\partial V}\bold{A}\cdot d\bold{\sigma}=\int_V\nabla\cdot\bold{A}d\tau\\\\ \end{aligned}∮∂V​A⋅dσ=∫V​∇⋅Adτ​

​ Notice that if the region of interest is the complete R3\R^3R3 , and the volume integral converges , the surface integral must vanish , giving that

∫∇⋅Adτ=0 ,integration   over   R3   and   convergent.\begin{aligned} \int\nabla\cdot\bold{A}d\tau=0\,,\quad integration\,\,\,over\,\,\,\R^3\,\,\,and\,\,\,convergent.\\ \end{aligned}∫∇⋅Adτ=0,integrationoverR3andconvergent.​

□\square□ Green’s Theorem

​ A frequently useful corollary of Gauss’ theorem is a relation known as Green’s theorem\textbf{Green's theorem}Green’s theorem. If uuu and vvv are two scalar functions , we have

∇⋅(u∇v)=u∇2v+(∇u)⋅(∇v)\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot(u\nabla v)=u\nabla^2v+(\nabla u)\cdot(\nabla v)\\\\ \end{aligned}∇⋅(u∇v)=u∇2v+(∇u)⋅(∇v)​

​ Also we have

∇⋅(v∇u)=v∇2u+(∇v)⋅(∇u)\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot(v\nabla u)=v\nabla^2u+(\nabla v)\cdot(\nabla u)\\\\ \end{aligned}∇⋅(v∇u)=v∇2u+(∇v)⋅(∇u)​

​ So there is

u∇2v−v∇2u=∇⋅(u∇v)−∇⋅(v∇u)\begin{aligned} u\nabla^2v-v\nabla^2u=\nabla\cdot(u\nabla v)-\nabla\cdot(v\nabla u)\\\\ \end{aligned}u∇2v−v∇2u=∇⋅(u∇v)−∇⋅(v∇u)​

​ Thus , applying Gauss’ theorem , we obtain

∫V(u∇2v−v∇2u)dτ=∮∂V(u∇v−v∇u)⋅dσ⃗\begin{aligned} \int_V(u\nabla^2v-v\nabla^2u)d\tau=\oint_{\partial V}(u\nabla v-v\nabla u)\cdot d\vec{\sigma}\\\\ \end{aligned}∫V​(u∇2v−v∇2u)dτ=∮∂V​(u∇v−v∇u)⋅dσ​

​ This is Green’s theorem. An alternative of Green’s theorem is

∮∂Vu∇v⋅dσ⃗=∫Vu∇2vdτ+∫V(∇u)⋅(∇v)dτ\begin{aligned} \oint_{\partial V}u\nabla v\cdot d\vec{\sigma}=\int_Vu\nabla^2vd\tau+\int_V(\nabla u)\cdot(\nabla v)d\tau\\\\ \end{aligned}∮∂V​u∇v⋅dσ=∫V​u∇2vdτ+∫V​(∇u)⋅(∇v)dτ​

​ These results we have already obtained are of great importance. For instance , consider a vector field B(x,y,z)\bold{B}(x,y,z)B(x,y,z) which satisfies that B(x,y,z)=B(x,y,z)a\bold{B}(x,y,z)=B(x,y,z)\bold{a}B(x,y,z)=B(x,y,z)a , in which a\bold{a}a is a constant vector to an arbitrary direction. Applying the equation above , we can get

a⋅∮∂VB dσ⃗=∫V∇⋅(Ba)dτ=a⋅∫V∇B dτ⟹a⋅[∮∂VB dσ⃗−∫V∇B dτ]=0⟹∮∂VB dσ⃗=∫V∇B dτ\begin{aligned} &\bold{a}\cdot\oint_{\partial V}B\,d\vec{\sigma}=\int_V\nabla\cdot(B\bold{a})d\tau=\bold{a}\cdot\int_V\nabla B\,d\tau\\\Longrightarrow&\quad\bold{a}\cdot[\oint_{\partial V}B\,d\vec{\sigma}-\int_V\nabla B\,d\tau]=0\\\Longrightarrow&\quad\oint_{\partial V}B\,d\vec{\sigma}=\int_V\nabla B\,d\tau\\\\ \end{aligned}⟹⟹​a⋅∮∂V​Bdσ=∫V​∇⋅(Ba)dτ=a⋅∫V​∇Bdτa⋅[∮∂V​Bdσ−∫V​∇Bdτ]=0∮∂V​Bdσ=∫V​∇Bdτ​

​ In a similar manner , using \bold{B}=\bold{a}\cross\bold{P} in which a\bold{a}a is a constant vector , we may show

\begin{aligned} \oint_{\partial V}d\vec{\sigma}\cross\bold{P}=\int_V\nabla\cross\bold{P}d\tau\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ These last two forms of Gauss’ theorem are used in the vector form of Kirchhoff diffraction theory.

□\square□ Stokes’ Theorem

​ This theorem relates a surface integral of a derivative of a function to the line integral of the function , with the path of integration being the perimeter bounding the surface.

​ The theorem states that

\begin{aligned} \int_Sd\vec{\sigma}\cross\nabla \varphi&=\oint_{\partial S}\varphi d\bold{r}\\\int_S(d\vec{\sigma}\cross\nabla)\cross\bold{P}&=\oint_{\partial S}d\bold{r}\cross\bold{P}\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ These can be applied in Faraday’s law and Oersted’s law.

\S3.9 Potential Theory

​ In some fields of physics , we introduce potential\textbf{potential}potential to simplify our problems.

□\square□ Scalar Potential

​ If in a simply connected region of space , an irrotational vector field can be expressed as the negative gradient of a scalar function φ\varphiφ :

F=−∇φ\begin{aligned} \bold{F}=-\nabla\varphi\\\\ \end{aligned}F=−∇φ​

​ We call φ\varphiφ a scalar potential\textbf{scalar potential}scalar potential , and this simplifies the F\bold{F}F (three functions) into one function. Notice that F\bold{F}F is a derivative , so the potential is only determined up to a additive constant , which can be used to adjust its value at infinity (usually zero) or at some other reference point.

​ Consider

−∫ABF⋅dr=∫AB∇φ⋅dr=φ(rB)−φ(rA)\begin{aligned} -\int_A^B\bold{F}\cdot d\bold{r}=\int_A^B\nabla\varphi\cdot d\bold{r}=\varphi(\bold{r}_B)-\varphi(\bold{r}_A)\\\\ \end{aligned}−∫AB​F⋅dr=∫AB​∇φ⋅dr=φ(rB​)−φ(rA​)​

​ Thus we can conclude that F\bold{F}F is irrotational , or to say , is conservative\textbf{conservative}conservative , because

∮F⋅dr=0\begin{aligned} \oint\bold{F}\cdot d\bold{r}=0\\\\ \end{aligned}∮F⋅dr=0​

□\square□ Vector Potential

​ A solenoidal force field can be written as \bold{B}=\nabla\cross\bold{A}.

​ Our construction is

A=e^y∫x0xBz(x,y,z)dx+e^z[∫y0yBx(x,y,z)dy−∫x0xBy(x,y,z)dx]\begin{aligned} \bold{A}=\hat{\bold{e}}_y\int_{x_0}^xB_z(x,y,z)dx+\hat{\bold{e}}_z[\int_{y_0}^yB_x(x,y,z)dy-\int_{x_0}^xB_y(x,y,z)dx]\\\\ \end{aligned}A=e^y​∫x0​x​Bz​(x,y,z)dx+e^z​[∫y0​y​Bx​(x,y,z)dy−∫x0​x​By​(x,y,z)dx]​

​ Checking the yyy- and zzz-components of \nabla\cross\bold{A} first , noting that Ax=0A_x=0Ax​=0 ,

\begin{aligned} (\nabla\cross\bold{A})_y&=-\frac{\partial A_z}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\int_{x_0}^xB_y(x,y,z)dx=B_y\\ (\nabla\cross\bold{A})_z&=\frac{\partial A_y}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\int_{x_0}^xB_z(x,y,z)dx=B_z\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ The xxx-component :

\begin{flalign} (\nabla\cross\bold{A})_x&=\frac{\partial A_z}{\partial y}-\frac{\partial A_y}{\partial z}\\&=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}[\int_{y_0}^yB_x(x,y,z)dy-\int_{x_0}^xB_y(x,y,z)dx]-\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\int_{x_0}^xB_z(x,y,z)dx\\&=B_x(x_0,y,z)-\int_{x_0}^x[\frac{\partial B_y(x,y,z)}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial B_z(x,y,z)}{\partial z}]dx\\\\ \end{flalign}

​ B\bold{B}B is solenoidal , so ∇⋅B=0\nabla\cdot\bold{B}=0∇⋅B=0. Then

∂By(x,y,z)∂y+∂Bz(x,y,z)∂z=−∂Bx(x,y,z)∂x\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial B_y(x,y,z)}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial B_z(x,y,z)}{\partial z}=-\frac{\partial B_x(x,y,z)}{\partial x}\\\\ \end{aligned}∂y∂By​(x,y,z)​+∂z∂Bz​(x,y,z)​=−∂x∂Bx​(x,y,z)​​

​ So

\begin{aligned} (\nabla\cross\bold{A})_x=B_x(x,y,z)-B_x(x_0,y,z)=B_x\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ Actually , A\bold{A}A is far from unique , as we can add to it the gradient of any\textbf{any}any scalar function. Moreover , our verification of A\bold{A}A was independent of the values of x0x_0x0​ and y0y_0y0​. In addition , we can derive another formula for A\bold{A}A in which the roles of xxx and yyy are interchanged :

A=−e^x∫y0yBz(x,y,z)dy−e^z[∫x0xBy(x,y,z)dx−∫y0yBx(x,y,z)dy]\begin{aligned} \bold{A}=-\hat{\bold{e}}_x\int_{y_0}^yB_z(x,y,z)dy-\hat{\bold{e}}_z[\int_{x_0}^xB_y(x,y,z)dx-\int_{y_0}^yB_x(x,y,z)dy]\\\\ \end{aligned}A=−e^x​∫y0​y​Bz​(x,y,z)dy−e^z​[∫x0​x​By​(x,y,z)dx−∫y0​y​Bx​(x,y,z)dy]​

​ Thus , we may introduce different kinds of gauge to restrict the vector potential. In electromagnetic theories , there are Lorentz gauge\textbf{Lorentz gauge}Lorentz gauge :

1c2∂φ∂t+∇⋅A=0\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{c^2}\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial t}+\nabla\cdot\bold{A}=0\\\\ \end{aligned}c21​∂t∂φ​+∇⋅A=0​

​ and Coulomb gauge\textbf{Coulomb gauge}Coulomb gauge :

∇⋅A=0\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot\bold{A}=0\\\\ \end{aligned}∇⋅A=0​

​ and transformations of A\bold{A}A and φ\varphiφ to satisfy them or other legitimate gauge condition are called gauge transformations\textbf{gauge transformations}gauge transformations.

□\square□ Gauss’ Law

​ The Gauss’ law states that for an arbitrary volume VVV ,

∮∂VE⋅dσ⃗=qε0\begin{aligned} \oint_{\partial V}\bold{E}\cdot d\vec{\sigma}=\frac{q}{\varepsilon_0}\\\\ \end{aligned}∮∂V​E⋅dσ=ε0​q​​

​ qqq is the charge in the volume.

​ To prove this law , notice that the case that ∂V\partial V∂V does not enclose qqq is easy to handle. If there is no charge in the volume , then ∇⋅E=0\nabla\cdot\bold{E}=0∇⋅E=0 is satisfied throughout the entire volume VVV. Thus ,

∫V∇⋅E=0  ⟶  E⋅dσ⃗=0\begin{aligned} \int_V\nabla\cdot\bold{E}=0\,\,\longrightarrow\,\,\bold{E}\cdot d\vec{\sigma}=0\\\\ \end{aligned}∫V​∇⋅E=0⟶E⋅dσ=0​

​ If qqq is within the volume VVV , we must be more devious. We can use a volume as below.

​ We now consider ∮E⋅dσ⃗\oint\bold{E}\cdot d\vec{\sigma}∮E⋅dσin the surface of this modified volume. The contribution from the connecting tube will become negligible in the limit that it shrinks toward zero cross section , as E\bold{E}E is finite everywhere on the tube’s surface. The integral over the modified ∂V′\partial V'∂V′ will thus be that of the original ∂V\partial V∂V (over the outer boundary , which we designate SSS) , plus that of the inner spherical surface (S′S'S′).

​ But note that the “outward” direction for S′S'S′ is toward smaller rrr , so dσ⃗′=−r^dAd\vec{\sigma}'=-\hat{\bold{r}}dAdσ′=−r^dA. We have

∮∂V′E⋅dσ⃗=∮SE⋅dσ⃗+q4πε0∮S′r^⋅dσ⃗′δ2=0\begin{aligned} \oint_{\partial V'}\bold{E}\cdot d\vec{\sigma}=\oint_S\bold{E}\cdot d\vec{\sigma}+\frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\oint_{S'}\frac{\hat{\bold{r}}\cdot d\vec{\sigma}'}{\delta^2}=0\\\\ \end{aligned}∮∂V′​E⋅dσ=∮S​E⋅dσ+4πε0​q​∮S′​δ2r^⋅dσ′​=0​

​ There is dA=δ2dΩdA=\delta^2d\OmegadA=δ2dΩ , so

∮S′r^⋅dσ⃗′δ2=∫r^δ2⋅(−r^δ2dΩ)=−∫dΩ=−4π\begin{aligned} \oint_{S'}\frac{\hat{\bold{r}}\cdot d\vec{\sigma}'}{\delta^2}=\int\frac{\hat{\bold{r}}}{\delta^2}\cdot(-\hat{\bold{r}}\delta^2d\Omega)=-\int d\Omega=-4\pi\\\\ \end{aligned}∮S′​δ2r^⋅dσ′​=∫δ2r^​⋅(−r^δ2dΩ)=−∫dΩ=−4π​

​ Then

∮SE⋅dσ⃗=−q4πε0(−4π)=qε0\begin{aligned} \oint_S\bold{E}\cdot d\vec{\sigma}=-\frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}(-4\pi)=\frac{q}{\varepsilon_0}\\\\ \end{aligned}∮S​E⋅dσ=−4πε0​q​(−4π)=ε0​q​​

​ We can also use its differential form

∇⋅E=ρε0\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot\bold{E}=\frac{\rho}{\varepsilon_0}\\\\ \end{aligned}∇⋅E=ε0​ρ​​

​ Thus we can see that Gauss’ law is the integral form of one of Maxwell’s equations.

□\square□ Poisson’s Equation

​ Assuming a situation independent of time , write E=−∇φ\bold{E}=-\nabla\varphiE=−∇φ , we obtain

∇2φ=−ρε0\begin{aligned} \nabla^2\varphi=-\frac{\rho}{\varepsilon_0}\\\\ \end{aligned}∇2φ=−ε0​ρ​​

​ This kind of equation is called Poisson’s equation\textbf{Poisson's equation}Poisson’s equation. For a more special situation , ∇2φ=0\nabla^2\varphi=0∇2φ=0 is called Laplace’s equation\textbf{Laplace's equation}Laplace’s equation.

​ Here , we are going to consider a particular situation. To make Poisson’s equation apply to a point chare qqq , the Dirac delta function is what we need. Thus , we write

∇2φ=−qε0δ(r)\begin{aligned} \nabla^2\varphi=-\frac{q}{\varepsilon_0}\delta(\bold{r})\\\\ \end{aligned}∇2φ=−ε0​q​δ(r)​

​ For charge qqq at r=0\bold{r}=0r=0. Inserting the point-charge potential for φ\varphiφ , we have

q4πε0∇2(1r)=−qε0δ(r)⟹∇2(1r)=−4πδ(r)\begin{aligned} \frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\nabla^2(\frac{1}{r})&=-\frac{q}{\varepsilon_0}\delta(\bold{r})\\\Longrightarrow\nabla^2(\frac{1}{r})&=-4\pi\delta(\bold{r})\\\\ \end{aligned}4πε0​q​∇2(r1​)⟹∇2(r1​)​=−ε0​q​δ(r)=−4πδ(r)​

​ This means the derivatives of 1/r1/r1/r is meaningless at the point r=0\bold{r}=0r=0 , and only if applied in a integral can it be meaningful. Also ,

∇12(1∣r1−r2∣)=−4πδ(r1−r2)\nabla_1^2(\frac{1}{|\bold{r}_1-\bold{r}_2|})=-4\pi\delta(\bold{r}_1-\bold{r}_2)\\\\∇12​(∣r1​−r2​∣1​)=−4πδ(r1​−r2​)

□\square□ Helmholtz’s Theorem

​ We now turn to two important theorems which establish conditions for the existence and uniqueness of solutions to time-independent problems in electromagnetic theory.

Claim 1

​ A vector field is uniquely specified by giving its divergence and its curl within a simply connected region and its normal component on the boundary.

​ Let P\bold{P}P be a vector field satisfying the conditions

\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot\bold{P}=s\,,\quad\nabla\cross\bold{P}=\bold{c}\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ where sss may be interpreted as a given source (charge) density and c\bold{c}c as a given circulation (current) density. Assuming that the normal component PnP_nPn​ on the boundary is also given , we want to show that P\bold{P}P is unique.

​ The proof goes by assuming the existence of a different vector field P′\bold{P}'P′ , which also satisfies those criteria. Consider Q=P−P′\bold{Q}=\bold{P}-\bold{P}'Q=P−P′ , which must have ∇⋅Q=0\nabla\cdot\bold{Q}=0∇⋅Q=0 , \nabla\cross\bold{Q}=0 , and Qn=0Q_n=0Qn​=0 identically. So there is Q=−∇φ\bold{Q}=-\nabla\varphiQ=−∇φ , ∇2φ=0\nabla^2\varphi=0∇2φ=0.

​ Now apply Green’s theorem ,

∮∂Vu∇v⋅dσ⃗=∫Vu∇2v dτ+∫V(∇u)⋅(∇v) dτ⟹∮∂Vφ∇φ⋅dσ⃗=∫Vφ∇2φ dτ+∫V(∇φ)⋅(∇φ) dτ\begin{aligned} \oint_{\partial V}u\nabla v\cdot d\vec{\sigma}&=\int_Vu\nabla^2v\,d\tau+\int_V(\nabla u)\cdot(\nabla v)\,d\tau\\\Longrightarrow\oint_{\partial V}\varphi\nabla\varphi\cdot d\vec{\sigma}&=\int_V\varphi\nabla^2\varphi\,d\tau+\int_V(\nabla\varphi)\cdot(\nabla\varphi)\,d\tau\\\\ \end{aligned}∮∂V​u∇v⋅dσ⟹∮∂V​φ∇φ⋅dσ​=∫V​u∇2vdτ+∫V​(∇u)⋅(∇v)dτ=∫V​φ∇2φdτ+∫V​(∇φ)⋅(∇φ)dτ​

​ But Qn=0Q_n=0Qn​=0 , so ∇φ⋅dσ⃗=0\nabla\varphi\cdot d\vec{\sigma}=0∇φ⋅dσ=0 everywhere on ∂V\partial V∂V. Thus we obtain

∫V(∇φ)⋅(∇φ) dτ=∫VQ⋅Q dτ=0\begin{aligned} \int_V(\nabla\varphi)\cdot(\nabla\varphi)\,d\tau=\int_V\bold{Q}\cdot\bold{Q}\,d\tau=0\\\\ \end{aligned}∫V​(∇φ)⋅(∇φ)dτ=∫V​Q⋅Qdτ=0​

​ This can only be satisfied if Q\bold{Q}Q is identically zero throughout the region. Therefore P=P′\bold{P}=\bold{P}'P=P′.

​ Q.E.D□Q.E.D\quad\squareQ.E.D□

Claim 2

​ A vector P\bold{P}P with both source and circulation densities vanishing at infinity may be written as the sum of two parts , one of which is irrotational , the other of which is solenoidal.

​ Then P\bold{P}P can be written as \bold{P}=-\nabla\varphi+\nabla\cross\bold{A}. There is also s=∇⋅Ps=\nabla\cdot\bold{P}s=∇⋅P and \bold{c}=\nabla\cross\bold{P} defined well.

​ The formulas proposed for φ\varphiφ and A\bold{A}A are as following ,

φ(r1)=14π∫s(r2)r12dτ2A(r1)=14π∫c(r2)r12dτ2\begin{aligned} \varphi(\bold{r}_1)=\frac{1}{4\pi}\int\frac{s(\bold{r}_2)}{r_{12}}d\tau_2\\ \bold{A}(\bold{r}_1)=\frac{1}{4\pi}\int\frac{\bold{c}(\bold{r}_2)}{r_{12}}d\tau_2\\\\ \end{aligned}φ(r1​)=4π1​∫r12​s(r2​)​dτ2​A(r1​)=4π1​∫r12​c(r2​)​dτ2​​

​ Then ,

\begin{aligned} \nabla\cdot\bold{P}&=-\nabla\cdot\nabla\varphi+\nabla\cdot(\nabla\cross\bold{A})=-\nabla^2\varphi=s\\\\ \nabla\cross\bold{P}&=-\nabla\cross\nabla\varphi+\nabla\cross(\nabla\cross\bold{A})=\nabla\cross(\nabla\cross\bold{A})=\bold{c}\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ What we need to do is just check these equation. First , check that −∇2φ=s-\nabla^2\varphi=s−∇2φ=s , we examine

−∇12φ(r1)=−14π∫∇12(1r12)s(r2)dτ2=−14π∫[−4πδ(r1−r2)]s(r2)dτ2=s(r1)Q.E.D□\begin{aligned} -\nabla^2_1\varphi(\bold{r}_1)&=-\frac{1}{4\pi}\int\nabla^2_1(\frac{1}{r_{12}})s(\bold{r}_2)d\tau_2\\&=-\frac{1}{4\pi}\int[-4\pi\delta(\bold{r}_1-\bold{r}_2)]s(\bold{r}_2)d\tau_2\\&=s(\bold{r}_1)\\\\ Q.E.D\quad\square\\\\ \end{aligned}−∇12​φ(r1​)Q.E.D□​=−4π1​∫∇12​(r12​1​)s(r2​)dτ2​=−4π1​∫[−4πδ(r1​−r2​)]s(r2​)dτ2​=s(r1​)​

​ Now check that \nabla\cross(\nabla\cross\bold{A})=\bold{c}. There is

\nabla_1\cross(\nabla_1\cross\bold{A})=\nabla_1(\nabla_1\cdot\bold{A})-\nabla^2\bold{A}=\bold{c}\\\\

​ We look first at

∇1(∇1⋅A(r1))=14π∇1∫∇1⋅(c(r2)r12)dτ2=14π∇1∫c(r2)⋅∇1(1r12)dτ2=14π∇1∫c(r2)[−∇2(1r12)]dτ2\begin{aligned} \nabla_1(\nabla_1\cdot\bold{A}(\bold{r}_1))&=\frac{1}{4\pi}\nabla_1\int\nabla_1\cdot(\frac{\bold{c}(\bold{r}_2)}{r_{12}})d\tau_2\\&=\frac{1}{4\pi}\nabla_1\int\bold{c}(\bold{r}_2)\cdot\nabla_1(\frac{1}{r_{12}})d\tau_2\\&=\frac{1}{4\pi}\nabla_1\int\bold{c}(\bold{r}_2)[-\nabla_2(\frac{1}{r_{12}})]d\tau_2\\\\ \end{aligned}∇1​(∇1​⋅A(r1​))​=4π1​∇1​∫∇1​⋅(r12​c(r2​)​)dτ2​=4π1​∇1​∫c(r2​)⋅∇1​(r12​1​)dτ2​=4π1​∇1​∫c(r2​)[−∇2​(r12​1​)]dτ2​​

​ Now , integrate by parts , we have an equation (from example 3.7.3)

\begin{aligned} \int f(\bold{r})\nabla\cdot\bold{A}(\bold{r})d^3r&=-\int\bold{A}(\bold{r})\cdot\nabla f(\bold{r})d^3 r\\\int\bold{C}(\bold{r})\cdot(\nabla\cross\bold{A}(\bold{r}))d^3r&=\int\bold{A}(\bold{r})\cdot(\nabla\cross\bold{C}(\bold{r}))d^3r\\\\ \end{aligned}

​ Apply on the problem , we get

∇1(∇1⋅A(r1))=14π∇1∫(∇2⋅c(r2))(1r12)dτ2=0\begin{aligned} \nabla_1(\nabla_1\cdot\bold{A}(\bold{r}_1))=\frac{1}{4\pi}\nabla_1\int(\nabla_2\cdot\bold{c}(\bold{r}_2))(\frac{1}{r_{12}})d\tau_2=0\\\\ \end{aligned}∇1​(∇1​⋅A(r1​))=4π1​∇1​∫(∇2​⋅c(r2​))(r12​1​)dτ2​=0​

​ Thus , we only need to check that −∇2A=c-\nabla^2\bold{A}=\bold{c}−∇2A=c. For component jjj ,

−∇12Aj(r1)=−14π∫cj(r2)∇12(1r12)dτ2=−14π∫cj(r2)[−4πδ(r1−r2)]dτ2=cj(r1)Q.E.D□\begin{aligned} -\nabla^2_1A_j(\bold{r}_1)&=-\frac{1}{4\pi}\int c_j(\bold{r}_2)\nabla_1^2(\frac{1}{r_{12}})d\tau_2\\&=-\frac{1}{4\pi}\int c_j(\bold{r}_2)[-4\pi\delta(\bold{r}_1-\bold{r}_2)]d\tau_2\\&=c_j(\bold{r}_1)\\\\Q.E.D\quad\square\\\\ \end{aligned}−∇12​Aj​(r1​)Q.E.D□​=−4π1​∫cj​(r2​)∇12​(r12​1​)dτ2​=−4π1​∫cj​(r2​)[−4πδ(r1​−r2​)]dτ2​=cj​(r1​)​

\S3.10 Curvilinear Coordinates

□\square□ Orthogonal Coordinates in R3\R^3R3

​ In Cartesian coordinates , a point (x0,y0,z0)(x_0,y_0,z_0)(x0​,y0​,z0​) can be identified as the intersection of three planes , x=x0x=x_0x=x0​ , y=y0y=y_0y=y0​ and z=z0z=z_0z=z0​. A change in xxx is a displacement normal\textbf{normal}normal to the plane x=x0x=x_0x=x0​ , so as the changes in yyy and zzz. Then those changes are always along the same directions marked as e^x\hat{\bold{e}}_xe^x​ , e^y\hat{\bold{e}}_ye^y​ and e^z\hat{\bold{e}}_ze^z​.

​ Now consider a spherical polar coordinate system as an example of a curvilinear coordinate system , with the picture below.

​ (The definition is well-known and I am not going to repeat it here.)

​ Important observations :

​ (1) General coordinates need not be lengths ;

​ (2) A surface of constant coordinate value may have a normal whose direction depends on position ;

​ (3) Surfaces with different constant values of a same coordinate need to be parallel ;

​ (4) Changes in the value of a coordinate may move r\bold{r}r in both an amount and a direction that depends on position.

​ It is obvious that these unit vectors are mutually perpendicular , meaning that a small displacement in one of those directions will not change the values of the other two coordinates. But , a “large” displacement would bring changes to the values , because the normals are position-dependent.

​ A coordinate system is said to be orthogonal\textbf{orthogonal}orthogonal if its unit vectors are mutually perpendicular.

​ It is significant to realize that

r≠re^r+θe^θ+φe^φ\begin{aligned} \bold{r}\neq r\hat{\bold{e}}_r+\theta\hat{\bold{e}}_\theta+\varphi\hat{\bold{e}}_\varphi\\\\ \end{aligned}r=re^r​+θe^θ​+φe^φ​​

​ because there is not a constant unit vector. So , the component formulas for V=Vre^r+Vθe^θ+Vφe^φ\bold{V}=V_r\hat{\bold{e}}_r+V_\theta\hat{\bold{e}}_\theta+V_\varphi\hat{\bold{e}}_\varphiV=Vr​e^r​+Vθ​e^θ​+Vφ​e^φ​ describe decompositions applicable to the point at which the vector is specified.

​ When we deal a question with an arbitrary curvilinear system , with coordinates labeled (q1,q2,q3)(q_1,q_2,q_3)(q1​,q2​,q3​) , we naturally consider how qiq_iqi​ changes with the Cartesian coordinates. In this case , xxx can be thought as a function of qiq_iqi​ , thus we have

dx=∂x∂q1dq1+∂x∂q2dq2+∂x∂q3dq3⟹(dr)2=(dx)2+(dy)2+(dz)2\begin{aligned} dx&=\frac{\partial x}{\partial q_1}dq_1+\frac{\partial x}{\partial q_2}dq_2+\frac{\partial x}{\partial q_3}dq_3\\\\\Longrightarrow(&dr)^2=(dx)^2+(dy)^2+(dz)^2\\\\ \end{aligned}dx⟹(​=∂q1​∂x​dq1​+∂q2​∂x​dq2​+∂q3​∂x​dq3​dr)2=(dx)2+(dy)2+(dz)2​

​ But

(dx)2=∑ij∂x∂qi∂x∂qjdqidqj\begin{aligned} (dx)^2=\sum_{ij}\frac{\partial x}{\partial q_i}\frac{\partial x}{\partial q_j}dq_idq_j\\\\ \end{aligned}(dx)2=ij∑​∂qi​∂x​∂qj​∂x​dqi​dqj​​

​ Thus

(dr)2=∑ijgijdqidqj\begin{aligned} (dr)^2=\sum_{ij}g_{ij}dq_idq_j\\\\ \end{aligned}(dr)2=ij∑​gij​dqi​dqj​​

​ where

gij(q1,q2,q3)=∂x∂qi∂x∂qj+∂y∂qi∂y∂qj+∂z∂qi∂z∂qj\begin{aligned} g_{ij}(q_1,q_2,q_3)=\frac{\partial x}{\partial q_i}\frac{\partial x}{\partial q_j}+\frac{\partial y}{\partial q_i}\frac{\partial y}{\partial q_j}+\frac{\partial z}{\partial q_i}\frac{\partial z}{\partial q_j}\\\\ \end{aligned}gij​(q1​,q2​,q3​)=∂qi​∂x​∂qj​∂x​+∂qi​∂y​∂qj​∂y​+∂qi​∂z​∂qj​∂z​​

​ Spaces with a measure of distance given as above are called metric\textbf{metric}metric or Riemannian\textbf{Riemannian}Riemannian.

​ The equation above can be seen as the dot product of two vectors , which are in the dqidq_idqi​ and dqjdq_jdqj​ direction. Thus , if the coordinate is perpendicular , the coefficients will vanish when i≠ji\neq ji=j.

​ Rewrite the equation as

(dr)2=(h1dq1)2+(h2dq2)2+(h3dq3)2hi2=(∂x∂qi)2+(∂y∂qi)2+(∂z∂qi)2⟹dri=hidqi ,or∂r∂qi=hie^i⟹dr=h1dq1e^1+h2dq2e^2+h3dq3e^3\begin{aligned} (dr)^2&=(h_1dq_1)^2+(h_2dq_2)^2+(h_3dq_3)^2\\\\ h_i^2&=(\frac{\partial x}{\partial q_i})^2+(\frac{\partial y}{\partial q_i})^2+(\frac{\partial z}{\partial q_i})^2\\\\\Longrightarrow\quad dr_i&=h_idq_i\,,\quad\text{or}\quad\frac{\partial \bold{r}}{\partial q_i}=h_i\hat{\bold{e}}_i\\\\\Longrightarrow\quad d\bold{r}&=h_1dq_1\hat{\bold{e}}_1+h_2dq_2\hat{\bold{e}}_2+h_3dq_3\hat{\bold{e}}_3\\\\ \end{aligned}(dr)2hi2​⟹dri​⟹dr​=(h1​dq1​)2+(h2​dq2​)2+(h3​dq3​)2=(∂qi​∂x​)2+(∂qi​∂y​)2+(∂qi​∂z​)2=hi​dqi​,or∂qi​∂r​=hi​e^i​=h1​dq1​e^1​+h2​dq2​e^2​+h3​dq3​e^3​​

​ Note that hih_ihi​ may be position-dependent. We call hih_ihi​ the scale factors or Lameˊ\text{Lam}\acute{\text{e}}Lameˊ coefficients.

□\square□ Integrals in Curvilinear Coordinates

​ After we introduced the definition of the scale factors , we can use them to set up formulas for integration in the curvilinear coordinates. There is

∫CV⋅dr=∑i∫CVihidqi\begin{aligned} \int_C\bold{V}\cdot d\bold{r}=\sum_i\int_CV_ih_idq_i\\\\ \end{aligned}∫C​V⋅dr=i∑​∫C​Vi​hi​dqi​​

​ Also surface integrals

∫SV⋅dσ=∫SV1h2h3dq2dq3+∫SV2h3h1dq3dq1+∫SV3h1h2dq1dq2\begin{aligned} \int_S\bold{V}\cdot d\bold{\sigma}=\int_SV_1h_2h_3dq_2dq_3+\int_SV_2h_3h_1dq_3dq_1+\int_SV_3h_1h_2dq_1dq_2\\\\ \end{aligned}∫S​V⋅dσ=∫S​V1​h2​h3​dq2​dq3​+∫S​V2​h3​h1​dq3​dq1​+∫S​V3​h1​h2​dq1​dq2​​

​ For volume integrals , they take the form as

dτ=h1h2h3dq1dq2dq3⟹∫Vφ(q1,q2,q3)h1h2h3dq1dq2dq3or∫VV(q1,q2,q3)h1h2h3dq1dq2dq3\begin{aligned} d\tau&=h_1h_2h_3dq_1dq_2dq_3\\\\ \Longrightarrow\quad&\int_V\varphi(q_1,q_2,q_3)h_1h_2h_3dq_1dq_2dq_3\\\\\text{or}\quad&\int_V\bold{V}(q_1,q_2,q_3)h_1h_2h_3dq_1dq_2dq_3\\\\ \end{aligned}dτ⟹or​=h1​h2​h3​dq1​dq2​dq3​∫V​φ(q1​,q2​,q3​)h1​h2​h3​dq1​dq2​dq3​∫V​V(q1​,q2​,q3​)h1​h2​h3​dq1​dq2​dq3​​

□\square□ Differential Operators in Curvilinear Coordinates

Gradient

​ Just replace dridr_idri​ by hidqih_idq_ihi​dqi​ :

∇φ(q1,q2,q3)=e^11h1∂φ∂q1+e^21h2∂φ∂q2+e^31h3∂φ∂q3\begin{aligned} \nabla\varphi(q_1,q_2,q_3)=\hat{\bold{e}}_1\frac{1}{h_1}\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial q_1}+\hat{\bold{e}}_2\frac{1}{h_2}\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial q_2}+\hat{\bold{e}}_3\frac{1}{h_3}\frac{\partial\varphi}{\partial q_3}\\\\ \end{aligned}∇φ(q1​,q2​,q3​)=e^1​h1​1​∂q1​∂φ​+e^2​h2​1​∂q2​∂φ​+e^3​h3​1​∂q3​∂φ​​

​ Thus ,

∇=e^11h1∂∂q1+e^21h2∂∂q2+e^31h3∂∂q3\nabla=\hat{\bold{e}}_1\frac{1}{h_1}\frac{\partial}{\partial q_1}+\hat{\bold{e}}_2\frac{1}{h_2}\frac{\partial}{\partial q_2}+\hat{\bold{e}}_3\frac{1}{h_3}\frac{\partial}{\partial q_3}\\\\∇=e^1​h1​1​∂q1​∂​+e^2​h2​1​∂q2​∂​+e^3​h3​1​∂q3​∂​

Divergence

​ The value of divergence must be the same as the value calculated in Cartesian coordinates , but the volume element is totally different from the former coordinate.
